variables.desc: The Z-machine is a virtual machine that was developed by Infocom in 1979 for its text adventure games. The Z-machine is a stack-based machine, which means that it uses a stack to store data and instructions. The Z-machine is also a virtual machine, which means that it is not a physical machine. Instead, it is a software program that emulates the behavior of a physical machine. The Z-machine was designed to be portable, which means that it can be run on a variety of different computer platforms. This allowed Infocom to release its games on a wide range of computers, including the Apple II, Commodore 64, and IBM PC.
